item.title: The Delta Emulator is changing its logo after Adobe threatened it
item.content:encoded:
https://www.theverge.com/2024/5/17/24159268/delta-emulator-logo-change-app

Delta Emulator is abandoning its current logo for a different, yet-to-be-revealed mark ‚Äî because Adobe thinks Delta‚Äôs stylized letter ‚ÄúD‚Äù is a bit too close to its stylized letter ‚ÄúA‚Äù for comfort.

It‚Äôs not every day you see an app changelog that includes news of a legal threat, but get a load of this:

Image via iOS App Store

The situation unfolded quickly, according to emails Delta creator Riley Testut shared with The Verge:

On May 7th, Adobe‚Äôs lawyers reached out to Delta with a firm but kindly written request to go find a different icon, an email that didn‚Äôt contain an explicit threat or even use the word infringement ‚Äî it merely suggested that Delta might ‚Äúnot wish to confuse consumers or otherwise violate Adobe‚Äôs rights or the law.‚Äù

But Adobe didn‚Äôt wait for a reply. On May 8th, one day later, Testut got another email from Apple that suggested his app might be at risk because Adobe had reached out to allege Delta was infringing its intellectual property rights.

‚ÄúWe responded to both Apple and Adobe explaining our icon was a stylized Greek letter delta ‚Äî not an A ‚Äî but that we would update the Delta logo anyway to avoid confusion,‚Äù Testut tells us.

The icon you‚Äôre seeing on the App Store now is just a temporary one, he says, as the team is still working on a new logo. ‚ÄúBoth the App Store and AltStore versions have been updated with this temporary icon, but the plan is to update them to the final updated logo with Delta 1.6 once it‚Äôs finished.‚Äù

Adobe does have one logo that‚Äôs pretty similar to Delta‚Äôs, and all of Adobe‚Äôs logos contain stylized triangles with an almost identically shaped gap. They‚Äôve had such a gap since 1982 when Marva Warnock, the wife of company co-founder John Warnock, first designed the mark.

But Adobe adopted a negative space version of the logo in 1993 and has used it ever since, one that‚Äôs harder to confuse with Delta:

I certainly didn‚Äôt think of Adobe when I first saw Delta‚Äôs logo.

item.title: F1 24 Q&A ‚Äì Codemasters Talks AI Improvements, Confirms NVIDIA DLSS 3 (Frame Gen) Support
item.content:encoded:
https://wccftech.com/f1-24-qa-codemasters-talks-ai-improvements-confirms-nvidia-dlss-3-frame-gen-support/

With two weeks left before the launch of F1 24, the latest installment in the licensed Formula 1 racing game series, we have sent a few questions to Codemasters to discuss some of the new features and improvements that fans will find in the game. The answers were provided by Senior Creative Director Lee Mather and Senior Producer Simon Lumb.

As a reminder, F1 24 debuts on May 31 on PC, PlayStation 4, PlayStation 5, Xbox One, and Xbox Series S|X. However, the Champions Edition ($20 more expensive than the Standard Edition) grants three days of early access, allowing owners to start playing on May 28.

What was the community's reaction to the announcements? Will you address some of the feedback that has emerged in the launch version and afterward, and if so, which?

Lee: We‚Äôve seen positive feedback to the F1 24 announcement and players have really engaged with the deep dive videos we‚Äôve delivered. Players are really excited about the handling and physics updates alongside the new Driver Career. As always, we‚Äôll be looking to log all player feedback once the game has launched. Players who have been part of our beta program have given feedback on stability, physics, handling, and AI, and we‚Äôve already made adjustments based on this.

What kind of tweaks and changes have been made to the AI?

Lee: With the significant changes in the physics and car setup in F1 24, the AI have also undergone a considerable amount of development to allow them to extract the best performance from the new model. This will be evident to the player in how they brake and exit corners and in the level of confidence they have when going wheel to wheel. The added stability of the cars this year impacts the ability of the AI to race cleanly in close proximity to the player.
Another area of major change in F1 24 is in how the AI will manage the updated ERS system. ERS management will have a significant impact on how both the player and the AI attack and defend.

What's your personal favorite new feature of F1 24?

Lee: I can never answer this with just one thing because most of the features in this year‚Äôs game are complementary to one another. We have the fantastic new Driver Career, which represents the world of F1, giving players so many ways to fulfill their goal of becoming an F1 World Champion or taking a team to the top of the Constructors Championship. None of this would be possible without an amazing and immersive on-track experience. The core of any racing game is how the cars feel and race and, of course, how great they look. These are both areas of significant advancement in F1 24.

Are there any improvements to the ray tracing features in F1 24?

Simon: Yes, in F1 24, we have extended the Ray Traced Dynamic Diffuse Global Illumination solution. DDGI is a technique that better represents the light response in shaded areas. This gives us an extra dose of realism in terms of softer shadows, light response, and light bounce across such dramatic F1 locations as a bright (or rainy!) Monaco, the unmatchable light show of Las Vegas, or the lush forest of Spa Francochamps.

NVIDIA's Shader Execution Reordering, a feature from RTX 40 GPUs that accelerates ray tracing performance, was supported at launch in F1 23 but did not work as intended and was subsequently removed. Will it be available in this new game?

Simon: Working with our partners at NVIDIA, we aim to give every user the best possible performance in F1 through our technology implementation. SER is a feature on their latest GPUs that helps with some specific ways that game engines work regarding Ray Tracing efficiency. When SER support was introduced in F1 23 at launch, we discovered that the technology did not provide enough benefit on the whole as EGO is already heavily optimized for the Ray Tracing workloads that SER was designed to improve in other engines. As there was no benefit for players, we removed the option from the UI. It remains off for F1 24.

What we have enabled in F1 24, which was not previously available in F1 23, is NVIDIA's Frame Generation performance solution. We hope that players with 40-series enjoy this upgrade for F1 24.

Will there be any graphics updates (e.g., higher rendering solution, etc.) for the VR version of the game?

Simon: The VR solution will benefit from all of the new graphical updates added to the engine, with compatible hardware and a sufficiently powerful GPU.

Will F1 24 support NVIDIA and AMD's frame generation techniques at launch?

Simon: F1 24 will support Frame Generation for NVIDIA GPUs.

Will the game support triple screens/surround setups?

Simon: As has been the case in previous games, the game can be stretched across as many monitors as you have VRAM for. It is not currently perspective-correct, so in a 3-monitor setup, the side monitors look more stretched than the middle one. The UI is always rendered in a 16:9 aspect ratio, so in a 3-monitor setup, it will appear on the middle monitor only.

We are continuing to evaluate how we might better support such set ups and appreciate the enthusiasm from our players who want to get as close to the sport as possible.

Are there any joystick support additions compared to last year?

Lee: We‚Äôve added support for the Turtle Beach Velocity One. With the changes to the physics this year, players will really feel what the car is doing beneath them on both a force feedback wheel or controller with rumble and haptic feedback.

Are there plans to ever bring back classic cars/tracks and integrate them in a more meaningful way?

Lee: We always have great fun with the classics and I‚Äôd never say never to them making a return at some point but there are no immediate plans for this. This year we‚Äôve really focused on delivering an improved, expanded and deeper modern day F1 experience. Of course, the legends are all playable as part of the new Driver Career which is really fun, being able to play with such legends as your teammate opens up a whole new way to play Career.

Will other racing series, such as Formula 3, ever be included in the future? Are there plans to bring back the paddock atmosphere from games like F1 2010, 2016, and 2017?

Lee: There are no immediate plans for this. We are currently hard at work and focusing on F1 24.

You've mentioned that F1 24 is still powered by EGO Engine, which is bespoke and currently best for the game. However, your fellow Codemasters team from EA WRC switched to Unreal Engine. Do you see yourselves considering the same option for next year?

Lee: The EGO engine which F1 is built upon is bespoke to F1. It‚Äôs what gives us our ability to move and change effectively, we are continuously adding new physics and rendering tech allowing us to keep the engine up to date and delivering the latest tech. The requirements of F1 and WRC are very different with WRC moving to Unreal to open up the opportunity to deliver a specific feature, that being long stages, which isn‚Äôt really a need for a track-based game like F1.

One of the key strengths of EGO is its ability to scale and deliver a high quality experience based on the hardware it‚Äôs being played on. While people might think it is the same engine, every year we adapt and grow EGO adjusting it to support what we want to achieve in the game that year.

Thank you for your time.

item.title: Twitch unbans shaking butts and twerking for animated emotes
item.content:encoded:
https://www.polygon.com/24159200/twitch-shaking-butts-twerking-emotes-unbanned

Finally, all those little dumpy Crewmates from Among Us can start shaking their asses on Twitch again. CEO Dan Clancy announced changes to the platform‚Äôs Community Guidelines on Wednesday, allowing cute animated emotes where characters shake their butts and twerk will be allowed on the platform.

Emotes help cultivate lively and active viewers in Twitch. Oftentimes, spamming emotes and using channel-specific icons in the chat can be just as fun as consuming the content itself. Now, the team is changing the emote content rules so that they‚Äôre in line with the general Community Guidelines. This means: time to twerk.

‚ÄúSo in particular emotes that feature shaking butts ‚Äî commonly referred to as twerking but we‚Äôll just call them shaking butts ‚Äî are now permitted under our guidelines,‚Äù Clancy said on Patch Notes livestream on Wednesday.

The banned emotes were never particularly graphic to begin with and impacted a lot of simple cartoon drawings. Twitch users reported strict moderation in response to the emotes in the summer on 2021. But now, those restrictions won‚Äôt apply. Polygon reached out to Twitch to ask about the change and a representative of the company replied with the following statement:

We set out to clarify how emotes are evaluated for approval by our teams. Before today, the guidelines we used to evaluate emote requests differed from our Community Guidelines, in some ways. We realize that this may have caused confusion, as it wasn‚Äôt always clear how we made approval decisions. Now, we‚Äôve brought our emote guidelines more in line with the rest of our Community Guidelines. We think this step will help to clarify our decision-making process for the community, something that‚Äôs important to us.

Twitch users have already embraced the change with open cheeks. Popular memes ‚Äî like a GIF where a Crewmate from Among Us shakes and bounces its butt ‚Äî will be able to make a return to Twitch chat. The ass-shaking has long been a popular format for emotes in general so artists have been responding by sharing art of various characters and other cute little drawings of characters shaking their butts. So if you‚Äôre a fan of cheeky art like of this voluptuous Kirby, well ,you‚Äôre in luck, because now you might see plenty of it on Twitch.

item.title: Animal Well: How To Solve The Three-Lever Wave Chart Puzzle
item.content:encoded:
https://kotaku.com/animal-well-three-lever-puzzle-guide-how-to-solve-1851485798

Animal Well is a very puzzle-driven game, and solving those puzzles often requires creative use of the items in your inventory. However, Animal Well also contains some standalone brainteasers that even a full set of tools can‚Äôt overcome. Take, for instance, the three-lever wave chart puzzle you‚Äôll encounter in the bottom-right quadrant of the map. You‚Äôll see a line on the wall alongside three dots, and you must use the levers beneath it to manipulate the shape of the line.

Kotaku‚Äôs Hopes For Spyro The Dragon‚Äôs (Reported) Comeback

  • Off
  • English

As you might have guessed, you‚Äôll solve this puzzle by adjusting the line so it passes through the three dots on the wall. Fortunately, you don‚Äôt have to get the line exactly through each dot; as long as you see each dot light up, it counts. The middle and right levers will manipulate the intensity of the line itself, while the left lever will wholesale move the line vertically.

The trick here is that you have to imagine what shape the line needs to be to hit all three lights at once. If, for example, you just try to pass through the first light, you may undo that work by the time you manipulate the line to hit the third light. Fortunately, you can adjust the levers to make the wave straightforwardly pass through the three lights in a gradual slope shape. Thinking of it that way may make the solution easier to visualize.

If you‚Äôre just sick of this puzzle and want the solution spelled out for you, check out the image below:

Note the position of the levers at the bottom. You‚Äôll want to position the left lever towards the bottom, and the middle lever should be tilted up. The right lever should be tilted slightly up, but remain relatively close to the center.

With the gate opened, you can open the treasure chest and obtain the Jade Egg.

But what‚Äôs with that fish head on the right side of the room?

Good question! If you‚Äôre still early in the game, you might be done here for now. However, if you find an item that blows bubbles, maybe the fish head will react in some way. Consider leaving yourself a reminder to check back here later on in your adventure.

item.title: 11 Things To Never Say To A Fallout 3 Fan
item.content:encoded:
https://kotaku.com/things-never-say-fallout-3-fan-new-vegas-bethesda-tv-1851485724

Following the release of Amazon‚Äôs live-action Fallout TV show, it seems everyone is playing a Fallout game again. Even Fortnite is adding Fallout content soon. It seems like the post-apocalyptic franchise is bigger than ever thanks to the recently released hit series.

So, with people talking about and playing all the Fallout games again, that naturally means a lot of discussion has happened, again, about which Fallout game is the best. People are ready to let you know that actually, Fallout 4 isn‚Äôt good, or that Fallout 76 is better than you heard. And you might even encounter some Fallout 3 fans out there, spreading the gospel that Bethesda‚Äôs first Fallout game is great. If you encounter these people, and I‚Äôm one of them, here are some tips on what not to say to them.

Are you in a rush or something? How about you relax and enjoy being born and growing up in a vault, okay?

It‚Äôs actually a really neat way of introducing the concept of Fallout‚Äôs vaults to people who might not be familiar with the franchise‚Äîwhich was most people when Fallout 3 launched. And hey, just save right before you enter the open world. You know, when the game lets you change everything one last time. Then start every new game from there, like most Fallout 3 fans.

Hey now, come on. Sure, a lot of Fallout 3 quests amount to ‚Äúgo here, chat, kill, grab, return‚Äù but there are plenty of other memorable quests in the game. Tenpenny Tower and the ghouls, the Survival Guide sidequest, and uh‚Ä¶oh that one quest where you can burn a tree-man-mutant to death. That was certainly memorable!

Oh, wait, what about that awesome side quest where you help ghouls go to space to escape the planet? Shit, that was in New Vegas. Oh actually, I loved that quest with cannibals in the casino‚Ä¶oh wait. That was also New Vegas. Okay, let‚Äôs move on.

Sure, you might want NPC companions to be interesting, spouting plenty of cool dialogue, and possessing memorable backgrounds that help you better connect with them. But what if they didn‚Äôt have that stuff? You might say that‚Äôs bad. That these NPCs are bland. I‚Äôd argue they help you focus on the world of Fallout 3 instead of getting distracted by good writing or fun character quirks. So thanks..uh‚Ä¶fuck, I forgot their names, but thanks nonetheless Fallout 3 companions.

‚Ä¶okay fair. I got nothing for that one.

Do you like smashing hammers on your fingers? Do you like eating broken glass? If so, you are clearly a masochist, and the pain you‚Äôll endure suffering through the poorly optimized and super buggy PS3 version of Fallout 3 will be a great experience for you. I‚Äôm happy you‚Äôre happy, truly! For everyone else: Buy Fallout 3 on PC and get some mods.

Oh, I‚Äôm so sorry the post-apocalyptic nuclear hellscape that is the ‚ÄúCaptial Wasteland‚Äù of Fallout 3 isn‚Äôt more colorful or pretty enough for you. I‚Äôm sorry that after that millions of people died and human civilization was vaporized‚Äîand while survivors live in a constant state of fear and starvation‚Äîyou have to look at some brown textures and green-tinted buildings.

How about this: Instead of complaining about Fallout 3‚Äôs drab environments and dreary landscape, you embrace it and become immersed in the dead world Bethesda has crafted.

Hey, welcome to 2024. We have had DLC for years now that retconned the last main quest‚Äôs sacrifice decision and got around that stupid‚ÄîI mean, completely understandable and well-written‚Äîending where your companions who aren‚Äôt phased by radiation tell you to fuck off and die.

You‚Äôre annoying.

Uh‚Ä¶wait‚Ä¶ what? *Boots up Fallout 3 and plays for 12 hours*

Huh‚Ä¶holy shit, I never noticed that. Yeah, that‚Äôs weird. Okay. I mean the game is still good and you‚Äôre wrong for pointing out any flaws, but I‚Äôll admit it‚Äôs weird. Happy?

Oh yeah, I‚Äôm so excited to play through New Vegas and its giant, empty, boring desert filled with annoying enemies, bugs, and repeated dialogue. No, thanks! I‚Äôll take my boring green subways instead.

I didn‚Äôt realize I was talking to someone who hated Alaska! Wow. That‚Äôs a bad look. Also, come on, Mothership Zeta was fun, too. Don‚Äôt be so mean. Okay. I‚Äôm a Fallout 3 fan. Life‚Äôs rough enough for me most days.

item.title: Leaks from Valve‚Äôs Deadlock look like a pressed sandwich of every game around
item.content:encoded:
https://arstechnica.com/?p=2025240

Deadlock isn't the most original name, but trademarks are hard ‚Äî

Is there something new underneath a whole bunch of familiar game elements?

"Basically, fast-paced interesting ADHD gameplay. Combination of Dota 2, Team Fortress 2, Overwatch, Valorant, Smite, Orcs Must Die."

That's how notable Valve leaker "Gabe Follower" describes Deadlock, a Valve game that is seemingly in playtesting at the moment, for which a few screenshots have leaked out.

The game has been known as "Neon Prime" and "Citadel" at prior points. It's a "Competitive third-person hero-based shooter," with six-on-six battles across a map with four "lanes." That allows for some of the "Tower defense mechanics" mentioned by Gabe Follower, along with "fast travel using floating rails, similar to Bioshock Infinite." The maps reference a "modern steampunk European city (little bit like Half-Life)," after "bad feedback" about a sci-fi theme pushed the development team toward fantasy.

Since testers started sharing Deadlock screenshots all over the place, here's ones I can verify, featuring one of the heroes called Grey Talon. pic.twitter.com/KdZSRxObSz

‚Äî ‚ÄéGabe Follower (@gabefollower) May 17, 2024

Valve doesn't release games often, and the games it does release are often in development for long periods. Deadlock purportedly started development in 2018, two years before Half-Life: Alyx existed. That the game has now seemingly reached a closed (though not closed enough) "alpha" playtesting phase, with players in the "hundreds," could suggest release within a reasonable time. Longtime Valve watcher (and modder, and code examiner) Tyler McVicker suggests in a related video that Deadlock has hundreds of people playing in this closed test, and the release is "about to happen."

McVicker adds to the descriptor pile-on by noting that it's "team-based," "hero-based," "class-based," and "personality-driven." It's an attempt, he says, to "bring together all of their communities under one umbrella."

Many of Valve's games do something notable to push gaming technology and culture forward. Half-Life brought advanced scripting, physics, and atmosphere to the "Doom clones" field and forever changed it. Counter-Strike and Team Fortress 2 lead the way in team multiplayer dynamics. Dota 2 solidified and popularized MOBAs, and Half-Life: Alyx gave VR on PC its killer app. Yes, there are Artifact moments, but they're more exception than rule.

Following any of those games seems like a tall order, but Valve's track record speaks for itself. I think players like me, who never took to Valorant or Overwatch or the like, should reserve judgment until the game can be seen in its whole. I have to imagine that there's more to Deadlock than a pile of very familiar elements.

item.title: Does EA Sports College Football 25 support cross-play?
item.content:encoded:
https://www.destructoid.com/does-ea-sports-college-football-25-support-cross-play/?utm_source=rss&utm_medium=rss&utm_campaign=does-ea-sports-college-football-25-support-cross-play

EA Sports College Football 25 features four core game modes and one-off classic online matches. Here is everything you need to know about which game modes support cross-play.

In the lead-up to its official release on July 19, EA Sports released a reveal trailer for College Football 25, which included a first look at pre-game rituals, stadium presentation, and gameplay. In addition to the video, the devs also released a blog detailing new features, game modes, and presentation. With all of that being said, one of the first questions at the top of players‚Äô minds is if they will be able to play the upcoming sports-sim title with friends on different consoles.

Cross-play in EA Sports College Football 25 will be available for players on PlayStation 5 and Xbox Series X|S in everything but Online Dynasty. There is no need to activate cross-play, as it will be enabled by default when you start the game for the first time on PS5 or Xbox Series X|S. On Xbox Series X|S, cross-play settings are controlled through the system settings. On PS5, these settings are found in the in-game settings.

The method for disabling cross-play differs by platform. On Xbox Series X|S, this must be done through the console system settings. On PS5, players can opt out of cross-play through the in-game settings.

Which EA Sports College Football 25 game modes support cross-play?

In College Football 25, Road to the College Football Playoff, College Football Ultimate Team, and Play a Friend support cross-platform. Unfortunately, players won‚Äôt be able to host an Online Dynasty server with friends on the other console.

How to start a cross-play game in EA Sports College Football 25

Here is a simple guide on how to host a cross-play game.

  • Open the EA connect menu in College Football 25
  • Navigate to the Player Search tab
  • Search for a player using their EA Identification number or their platform identifier. A player‚Äôs platform identifier is either their Xbox Series X|S gamertag or PSN ID

item.title: Best AR loadouts in Warzone
item.content:encoded:
https://www.destructoid.com/best-ar-loadouts-in-warzone/?utm_source=rss&utm_medium=rss&utm_campaign=best-ar-loadouts-in-warzone

ARs are very well balanced at the moment in Warzone. There isn‚Äôt one particular weapon that is significantly better than other options, and several rifles are worth using in standard battle royale matches or Resurgence.

Warzone‚Äôs long-range meta is usually dominated by LMGs because of their large magazine sizes and powerful damage output. Yet, in Modern Warfare 3‚Äôs iteration of Warzone, ARs tend to reign supreme as Resurgence has emerged as the more popular game mode, which has smaller maps that ARs perform better on thanks to their improved mobility. If you are a fan of ARs, here are the best options in Season 3 Reloaded.

Best AR loadouts in Warzone, ranked

5. BAL-27

  • Muzzle: ZEHM35 Compensated Flash Hider
  • Barrel: Crown-H3 Barrel
  • Underbarrel: Bruen Heavy Support Grip
  • Magazine: 60 Round Mag
  • Stock: Sandbard Heavy Stock

Without attachments to help improve recoil, the BAL-27 will feel like it‚Äôs bouncing all over the place while firing and too inconsistent to reliably take out an enemy 30 meters away or further. We did our best to mask that deficiency, but this AR still, unfortunately, gets outclassed in that category by other options. With that being said, the Sandbar Heavy Stock greatly improves recoil control, gun kick, aiming idle sway, and firing stability. In addition, the Bruen Heavy Support Grip also checks off all of those boxes to make the AR shoot more predictably.

4. Kastov 545

  • Muzzle: VT-7 Spirtfire Suppressor
  • Barrel: IG-K30 406mm
  • Underbarrel: Bruen Heavy Suport Barrel
  • Magazine: 60 Round Mag
  • Optic: JAK Glassless

Most MW2 weapons haven‚Äôt quite found a place in Warzone‚Äôs meta this year, but the Kastov 545 is a surprisingly consistent weapon that deals enough damage to compete with other popular weapons. Our loadout focuses on improving overall recoil and performance in medium to long-range engagements.

3.SVA 545

  • Muzzle: VT-7 Spiritfire Suppressor
  • Barrel: STV Prevision Barrel
  • Ammunition: 5.45 High Grain Rounds
  • Magazine: 60 Round Mag
  • Optic: JAK Glassless

Players can either decide to use the SVA in burst mode or fully-automatic fire. Either way, this AR will shred through enemies and is extremely easy to use. This rifle‚Äôs time-to-kill speed doesn‚Äôt jump off the page, but the weapon never suffers from a massive drop-off at longer ranges and won‚Äôt have any issues going toe-to-toe to with any other top-tier option.

2.MTZ 556

  • Muzzle: L4R Flash hider
  • Barrel: MTZ VLDL-3568 Barrel
  • Underbarrel: Chewk Angled Grip
  • Magazine: 50 Round Drum
  • Optic: MK.3 Reflector

Our loadout focuses on addressing all areas to round out the MTZ-556. The L4R Flash Hider, for example, improves recoil control and gun kick so the versatile AR can extend its range. Then, the MTZ VLDL-3568 Barrel improves ADS and sprint-to-fire speeds to make up for what‚Äôs lost from the barrel.

Next, the Chewk Angled Grip hits a little bit of everything, improving aiming idle sway, aiming walking speed, and horizontal recoil. With these attachments equipped, this loadout should have no issue taking on opponents up to 30 meters away. Anything else will require the sniper rifle. Finally, a 50-round drum makes it easier to take on multiple enemies simultaneously, while the MK.3 Reflector compensates for poor iron sights.

1. BP50

  • Muzzle: Casus Break
  • Barrel: LORE-9 Heavy Barrel
  • Underbarrel: DR-6 Handstop
  • Magazine: 45 Round Mag

Valve‚Äôs next game appears to be a multiplayer hero shooter known as Deadlock. This is according to leaks from playtesters posted on social media earlier today, with some of the details verified by known Valve data miner Tyler McVicker.

‚ÄúSince testers started sharing Deadlock screenshots all over the place, here‚Äôs ones I can verify, featuring one of the heroes called Grey Talon,‚Äù McVicker posted on X.

Another image shows a hero named Grey Talon and includes the character‚Äôs weapon and ability icons with a short description.

Combination of Dota 2, Team Fortress 2, Overwatch, Valorant, Smite, Orcs Must Die.‚Äù The Verge has reached out to Valve for comment.

Though Valve is now mostly known for its PC publishing platform Steam and the Steam Deck, the company is still making games. A new claim from a Call of Duty data miner suggests that the next Xbox console could launch as soon as 2026. The console would also feature that year‚Äôs Call of Duty as a launch title.

‚ÄúHearing from trusted sources that the next Xbox is planned to be released in late 2026,‚Äù The Ghost of Hope wrote. ‚ÄúVery likely that COD2026 is a day one release for it.‚Äù

Call of Duty 2026 is being developed by Infinity Ward. It‚Äôs also worth noting that Ghost of Hope has sources within Activision, which could be where his information is coming from.

Microsoft has gone on record multiple times in saying that a next-generation Xbox console would be coming. In an episode of the official Xbox podcast in February Xbox president Sarah Bond said that the company was exited about what‚Äôs coming with future Xbox hardware.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre also invested in the next-generation roadmap,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúWhat we‚Äôre really focused on there is delivering the largest technical leap you will have ever seen in a hardware generation, which makes it better for players and better for creators and the visions that they‚Äôre building.‚Äù

In April, according to an internal email, she reiterated the company was ‚Äúmoving full speed ahead‚Äù on the next system.

As far as a timeline for a next-gen console goes, it was discovered as part of the case investigation Microsoft‚Äôs purchase of Activision that the belief was that next-gen consoles from both Microsoft and Sony wouldn‚Äôt be coming until 2028. The document sourced in the case was from 2022.

In it‚Äôs most recent earnings, however, Microsoft says that Xbox hardware sales were down 31% year over year. That could change the timeline for getting its next console out the door.

Aside from a next-gen system, a new white Xbox Series X is expected to be released at some point.

It‚Äôs worth noting that nothing regarding the next generation Xbox console has been confirmed by Microsoft, and likely won‚Äôt be addressed. So, with any rumor like this that hasn‚Äôt been confirmed or independently verified by Insider Gaming, please take the claims with a grain of salt.

First published by Games Workshop in 1983, Talisman: The Magical Quest Game is remembered fondly by kids who grew up with board games in the 1980s and early 1990s. But the last version of the dungeon crawling board game, its fourth, was published way back in 2008, well before the modern board gaming Renaissance really began. Now Hasbro is bringing it back for a fifth edition. Pre-orders, priced at $59.99, are live now. The game returns to mass market retail on July 1.

In Talisman, players take on the role of stock fantasy heroes on the quest for a MacGuffin called the Crown of Command. The highly linear board game takes players round and round a citadel, where they encounter traps and monsters, and even fight against the other players at the table. It‚Äôs an unusual hybrid of an action-oriented tabletop role-playing game and something like Candyland, but a novel format that has resonated with generations of casual fans of tabletop games.

Polygon reached out to Hasbro following Friday‚Äôs press release. They confirmed that the IP hasn‚Äôt changed hands. Instead, the game is being produced under license from Games Workshop. Here‚Äôs the official description:

In the game, players set forth on an epic adventure, racing to be the first to obtain a Talisman, reach the Crown of Command in the center of the board, and defeat the elder dragon to win. With a diverse range of characters to choose from and a vast world of possible scenarios plus an easy to use, revised 5th Edition Rulebook, this strategy game offers limitless adventures!

While the game retains the traditional spiral game board, new cover art was revealed showing a crumbling staircase leading to a glowing crown while giant statues of gilded heroes look on. item.title: The Assassin‚Äôs Creed Heroes, Ranked From Worst To Best
item.content:encoded:
https://kotaku.com/assassins-creed-protagonists-heroes-best-worst-ranked-1851485549

Assassin‚Äôs Creed Shadows is adding two new heroes to the pantheon of brave and stealthy killers that span the centuries of the series‚Äô historical fiction. One is Naoe, a ninja who will don the hood and hidden blade commonly associated with the titular Assassins of Ubisoft‚Äôs open-world action franchise. The other is Yasuke, a Black samurai based on the historical figure of the same name. We don‚Äôt know much about either character just yet, but thinking about new Assassin‚Äôs Creed heroes naturally makes us reflect on the Assassins we‚Äôve inhabited over the years. So what better time than now to rank the heroes of the Assassin‚Äôs Creed franchise? Grab your hidden blades, it‚Äôs time to pit assassins against each other.

Alta√Ør, the protagonist of the first Assassin‚Äôs Creed, was the blueprint (derogatory) for how the franchise would portray its heroes. He was used to establish a format: a modern-day character uses the Animus, a virtual reality simulation, to view the memories of a historical ancestor. But in its first iteration, Assassin‚Äôs Creed seemed hesitant to make its hero more than an avatar for Desmond Miles, Alta√Ør‚Äôs modern-day descendant. He‚Äôs serviceable as a premise, but as a character? There‚Äôs probably a reason Ubisoft ditched him for Desmond‚Äôs far more popular ancestor, Ezio, in the sequel. ‚Äî Kenneth Shepard

‚ÄúDiscount Ezio‚Äù is the easiest, if not the nicest, way to describe the protagonist of Assassin‚Äôs Creed Unity. It‚Äôs also accurate. Arno lost his father and was raised by a wealthy family, making his origin similar to Ezio‚Äôs. They both do some brooding, too. But while Ezio is a charming vagabond who oozes personality and zest, Arno is the exact opposite. He spends most of Unity moping around, sulking, and being annoying. His story also runs out of steam by the end, but nobody really cares (not even Ubisoft) because everyone understandably forgot about Arno and moved on. -Zack Zwiezen

Poor Connor Kenway, born Ratonhnhak√©:ton, he deserved better. Assassin‚Äôs Creed III is a mess of a game and the biggest victim is Connor. The son of a Templar and a Native American woman, Connor struggles with his place in the world. While he ultimately ends up an Assassin, he often questions and criticizes the white leaders he‚Äôs forced to work alongside. It‚Äôs an intriguing setup.

But, sadly, Connor ends up acting more like a monotone broken record than a real character throughout the game‚Äôs main storyline. It doesn‚Äôt help that Ubisoft‚Äôs decision to make ACIII bigger than any previous game meant that Connor‚Äôs arc got covered in sidequests and busy work. -Zack Zwiezen

It‚Äôs a shame so few people played as Aveline de Grandpr√© when Assassin‚Äôs Creed III: Liberation launched on the Vita in 2012, because she‚Äôs an anomaly for the series even 12 years later. She was the first female protagonist in the series, and unlike future characters, she wasn‚Äôt a choice you could simply swap out, or sharing the spotlight with anyone else. Liberation follows her in the 1700s as the daughter of a freed slave who becomes inducted into the Assassin Brotherhood due to her attempts to free and protect slaves. The game makes great use of its period setting, and Aveline‚Äôs unique place in it, having her navigate different situations covertly by donning ‚Äúpersonas‚Äù to blend in with different elements of New Orleans society.

Thankfully, more people have gotten a chance to play her story in the years since its release on Sony‚Äôs handheld, as Liberation has been remastered and ported to every system under the sun. Still, there‚Äôs something damning about her resurgence, as it calls attention to the fact that Assassin‚Äôs Creed has been hesitant to give a character like her sole presence in the spotlight since. ‚Äî Kenneth Shepard

One half of the Frye twins who headline 2015‚Äôs Assassin‚Äôs Creed Syndicate, Jacob is a likable scoundrel who, frankly, is overshadowed by his even more charismatic and captivating sister. Jacob certainly has his moments of roguish charm, the ability to deploy a winning smile and defuse all the exasperation you were feeling toward him just a moment before. He‚Äôs also, at times, a rousing leader, as he attempts to organize the exploited poor of Victorian London and thwart their oppressors. However, Jacob can also come across as a real jerk sometimes, and the fact that Syndicate focuses more and more on him (and less on his sister) as it builds toward its climax feels like a miscalculation. Jacob is‚Ä¶fine, but if one of the Frye siblings had to be second fiddle, it should have been him.‚ÄîCarolyn Petit

Most Assassin‚Äôs Creed protagonists are heroes, more or less, but Shay Cormac is the big exception. As the star of Assassin‚Äôs Creed: Rogue, Shay lets us slide into the boots of someone who joins the Assassins and then leaves for the Templars after he loses faith in the Brotherhood‚Äôs motives and leaders.

What makes Shay such a compelling character is that Ubisoft does a good job of making him sympathetic, and his turn to the Templars seems reasonable. In a series that rarely puts a microscope on the Brotherhood, it‚Äôs refreshing to see Shay and his journey. Sure, maybe the Templars are worse, but Rogue and its star, Shay, make the case that the Assassins might not be as noble as the legends and its leaders suggest. -Zack Zwiezen

Assassin‚Äôs Creed: Valhalla‚Äôs Viking protagonist has a fair bit of baggage. Eivor is one of the more malleable playable characters in the series, as Valhalla is pretty entrenched in the choice-driven RPG genre that Assassin‚Äôs Creed has shifted into of late. But Eivor is also one of the weirdest attempts at dealing with canon while giving the player some freedom to make the character their own. Because of Assassin‚Äôs Creed‚Äôs mix of mythology and science fiction, Eivor is an incarnation of Odin, the Norse god. But you can play as either a male or female version of Eivor‚Ä¶only to find out that the male version is just Odin‚Äôs DNA being projected through the Animus.

Ubisoft put this in as a solution to making a specific Eivor ‚Äúcanon,‚Äù because now no matter what you do, Eivor was a woman and her male counterpart is just her previous iteration‚Äôs DNA confusing the virtual reality technology. But all this late-game twist does is make you ask why Assassin‚Äôs Creed can‚Äôt have a sole woman as its lead. It even ends up complicating things like its slew of gay romantic relationships for a male Eivor, asserting that they were secretly heterosexual ones the whole time. Valhalla‚Äôs choice-driven structures invite the player to define who Eivor can be, only to pull the rug out from under them in the eleventh hour.

Pushing all the baggage away with all your might, Eivor is a very likable protagonist. She‚Äôs caring, loves her clan, and is, interestingly enough, pretty separate from the usual Assassins vs. Templars storyline. I appreciate some of the interesting narrative swings Ubisoft took with her, but Eivor ends up being a case study in how the modern-day framing of historical fiction is both an asset and a disadvantage to the Assassin‚Äôs Creed series this many years in. ‚Äî Kenneth Shepard

If it wasn‚Äôt for Ad√©wal√©, Assassin‚Äôs Creed IV: Black Flag protagonist Edward Kenway would likely not have joined the Brotherhood at all. So that alone makes it worth giving Ad√©wal√© some extra credit. But Ad√©wal√© is more than just a sidekick of Edward.

He‚Äôs a slave who escaped that nightmare via the pirate‚Äôs life and who returns to help other freed slaves. As seen in the fantastic standalone DLC Freedom‚Äôs Cry, with Ad√©wal√©‚Äôs leadership and skill, this group of freed slaves helped disrupt the slave trade and likely saved many lives in the process. It‚Äôs just a shame his adventure was so short. -Zack Zwiezen

Basim Ibn Ishaq was first introduced as a mysterious and possibly dangerous Assassin in Assassin‚Äôs Creed: Valhalla. And, spoilers for that game, it‚Äôs eventually revealed that he‚Äôs actually the reincarnated Issu god Loki. Don‚Äôt worry about it. Anyway, 2023‚Äôs Assassin‚Äôs Creed: Mirage reveals Basim‚Äôs origins, including his early life as a street thief and his journey within the Brotherhood. Throughout Mirage it‚Äôs clear that Basim is being manipulated and yet, even as people he trusts betray him, the assassin never stops trying to help people.

And, like Ezio before him, Basim is a charming rogue, too. The people‚Äôs hero. Someone willing to always help the oppressed and fight the power, even if that means the Brotherhood itself. That makes the end of Mirage and Basim‚Äôs evolution into a more troubled villain‚Äîwho appears in Valhalla‚Äîall the more painful. He was once better than that. It also makes him one of the more complicated and nuanced protagonists in the franchise. -Zack Zwiezen

I admit, I haven‚Äôt played Syndicate since its release almost a decade ago, and I don‚Äôt deny that some of my enjoyment of Evie at the time rested in the novelty of her being (at long last!) the first playable female character in a mainline Assassin‚Äôs Creed game, albeit one who had to share the spotlight with her brother. But there‚Äôs more to her greatness than that. Where her hotheaded brother Jacob is reckless and unreasonable, Evie‚Äôs ability to stay cool under pressure makes her the real brains of the operation, making it all the more frustrating that the story increasingly focuses on Jacob as it progresses. She‚Äôs also genuinely charismatic and likable, which is especially important given how bleak and oppressive the streets of Victorian London can often feel. Evie isn‚Äôt naive about the horrible conditions of the city she lives in; far from it, she‚Äôs determined to do something about them. But rather than letting the gloom of it all infect her, she stays focused, clever, hopeful, and capable. And her battle-of-wits rapport with her brother is often delightful, leaving little doubt as to who‚Äôs the smarter and sharper of the two. Thankfully she wasn‚Äôt the last female protagonist in a mainline AC game, but as the first, she proved to be a terrific demonstration of how empty and absurd an excuse for their absence ‚Äúwomen are too hard to animate‚Äù had always been.‚ÄîCarolyn Petit

Assassin‚Äôs Creed IV: Black Flag holds a special place in fans‚Äô hearts for its sea-faring pirate spin on the franchise. A big part of why that tonal shift works so well is thanks to protagonist Edward Kenway. As a swashbuckling, brash assassin, he‚Äôs the opposite of what we‚Äôd been taught to expect from this series‚Äô heroes. No sly, subtle shadow operative, he‚Äôs more synonymous with bar fights and ship battles reeking of gunpowder. As such, he‚Äôs a rollicking, exciting hero to play whether he‚Äôs on land or sea, but he also has moments of quiet reflection that round him out. Shoutout to Constantine actor Matt Ryan for capturing the character‚Äôs emotional range in his lone video game credit. Get him in more games, I say. ‚Äî Kenneth Shepard

Assassin‚Äôs Creed: Odyssey‚Äôs Greek heroes, though distinct characters in the canon, serve the same role in the game regardless of which you choose to play as. Though Kassandra is technically the canonical choice, as per her appearance in Assassin‚Äôs Creed Valhalla, both embody the same bold, heroic nature. Like Eivor, Kassandra and Alexios are RPG protagonists that are somewhat defined by player choice, but they‚Äôre known for their headstrong and witty nature, which makes their heroics and human interactions memorable. Their journey culminates in a stunning final scene in which they survive until the modern day by using the Staff of Hermes. It‚Äôs fascinating that Kassandra and Alexios both set things into motion in their prime in Greece, and survive long enough to nudge the course of history once more in the present. They are heroic, charismatic, and some of the most memorable characters in the series. ‚Äî Kenneth Shepard

It‚Äôs almost impossible not to feel like Ezio Auditore da Firenze epitomizes Assassin‚Äôs Creed. First introduced to players in Assassin‚Äôs Creed II, the suave Italian stuck around longer than any other protagonist in the series. He got not one, not two, but three mainline games. What makes Ezio so enduring as an Assassin‚Äôs Creed protagonist is his undeniable charm and transformative story.

He starts as an uncaring rich boy and soon finds himself thrust into the path of the order after his father‚Äôs death. Assassin‚Äôs Creed II gives us the journey we all wanted from an AC game: the one that takes us from nobody to master Assassin. But Ezio‚Äôs story doesn‚Äôt stop with that. Starring in a trilogy turned Ezio into a much more complex character that players grew with through different stages of his life. It‚Äôs what makes his last outing, Revelations, remain so interesting. Whether an old man weighed down by a heavy life or a young brash kid out for revenge, Ezio is human and exceedingly well-portrayed in the series. There will simply never be another protagonist like him. ‚Äî Willa Rowe

As was said in our ranking of the Assassin‚Äôs Creed games, Origins‚Äô main star, Bayek, is the best protagonist in the franchise‚Äôs history. He‚Äôs both a nobleman trying to bring justice and peace everywhere he goes and a father mourning the loss of his child. Watching him try to help people while also dealing with so much rage leads to some of the best moments in Origins. It also doesn‚Äôt hurt that Bayek is extremely likable, and written with just enough charm and wit that he doesn‚Äôt feel like a boring vessel meant only to be controlled by the player.

Bayek and his wife, Aya, are also very important characters in the AC universe. They both essentially founded what would become the Brotherhood of Assassins out of the grief of losing their son to an evil man, and their journey for revenge would both destroy their relationship and change history forever. -Zack Zwiezen

item.title: Streamer‚Äôs Record-Breaking Cookie Baking Speedrun Leads To Chaos
item.content:encoded:
https://kotaku.com/qtcinderella-twitch-perfect-cookie-baking-speedrun-1851485609

Recipes are always lying about how long they take. Forty-five minutes to prep a lasagna. Twenty minutes to caramelize some onions. Fifteen minutes to bake cookies. Except in the case of cookie baking speedrunners, that‚Äôs actually not as outrageous as it sounds. In fact, it‚Äôs way longer than it took Twitch streamer QTCinderella to make a batch of 12 chocolate chip cookies. She completed the task in under four minutes earlier this week, throwing the cookie baking speedrun leaderboard into chaos in the process.

Kotaku‚Äôs Hopes For Spyro The Dragon‚Äôs (Reported) Comeback

  • Off
  • English

‚ÄúI AM THE CURRENT SPEED RUN RECORD HOLDER FOR A DOZEN COOKIES,‚Äù she tweeted on May 14. A snapshot of the Speedrun.com leaderboard showed recent players shredding the previous records, many of which were in the double digits. So how did QTCinderalla, a popular stream who has frequently incorporated baking into her content, including last year‚Äôs Master Baker Twitch competitions, manage to bake cookies in under four minutes?

The record-breaking run required a few significant time-saving tricks. The first was having all of the ingredients pre-measured, including oil substituted for butter. The second was having the oven and baking sheet pre-heated and extra hot. Finally, QTCinderalla used her hands to mix, a cookie scoop to quickly get blobs of dough on the cookie sheet, and then a second cookie sheet smooshed on top to expedite the baking process. It took roughly two minutes to get the confections in the oven and just 96 seconds to cook them to, well, maybe not perfection, but something surprisingly close. ‚ÄúStill moist, not raw, bitch,‚Äù she told her stream. ‚ÄúAnd they taste good!‚Äù

This was all in keeping with the loose rules of the speedrunning challenge, a niche IRL offshoot of the Cookie Clicker PC game category. In addition to being completely baked through, the cookies were also more than big enough at over three inches wide each. But not everyone was pleased with the record-setting breakthrough. Shortly after celebrating her victory, Speedrun.com decided to re-evaluate the category. ‚ÄúWe are temporarily archiving the IRL baking category in order to reevaluate the rules and come back with a more cohesive and comprehensive set of rules,‚Äù moderator TheStrahl wrote on the website. The new rules would codify things like which tools could be used and which cookies would pass the ‚Äúbaked‚Äù test.

‚ÄúThey are afraid of me,‚Äù QTCinderella tweeted in response.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not afraid, just trying to make the rules better before the inevitable shit storm of shitty speedruns you just sent my way,‚Äù TheStahl later responded. QTCinderalla wrote back,‚Äù Oh so I shouldn‚Äôt try to do a speed run on ? Fuck me right? The fun part of speed running is that ANYONE can do it. I think it‚Äôs COOL to draw attention to an unknown category. There is no reason to be rude.‚Äù

According to TheStahl, the speedrunning leaderboard gets swamped with spam, trolling, and other nonsense when niche categories blow up like this. New rules for the 12 cookie baking speedrun challenge have already been floated and they include things like contestants having to measure ingredients during the challenge rather than beforehand and making sure the finished cookies are circles and ‚Äúas close to round as possible.‚Äù

Things get even more intense after the run is complete and the cookies are tested to make sure they‚Äôre properly baked. ‚ÄúFirst the runner will pick up a cookie to show it is structurally sound,‚Äù the new proposed rules read. ‚ÄúThe aforementioned cookie must not completely break apart as a result. Show the bottom of the cookie to show that it has browned. The cookie will be broken in half to show that the cookie is cooked internally. Eat cookie.‚Äù

These draft rules may still be revised but they would certainly disqualify QTCinderalla‚Äôs existing record. It‚Äôs unclear if once they are settled she‚Äôll return to protect her legacy and reclaim her title. What I do know is that the next season of The Great British Bake Off needs to include a speedrunning challenge just like this one.

item.title: BSG Just Banned 30,000 Tarkov Cheaters, But It‚Äôs Not Enough
item.content:encoded:
https://insider-gaming.com/tarkov-cheaters-banned-battlestate/

Battlestate Games just confirmed that between March 15 and May 17, it banned more than 30,000 cheaters from Escape from Tarkov, the (decreasingly) popular extraction shooter. This news might come as a wonder to some, but for those familiar with the product, it‚Äôs just another day on the job. These ban waves seem to occur once every month or two, and despite BSG kicking out tens of thousands of cheaters every time, the number never seems to meaningfully decrease.

Constant.

Escape from Tarkov has a long-standing issue with cheaters. It‚Äôs a plague that has spoiled the game time and again over the years, and it has put off veteran players from continuing their extraction-based adventures and fully prevented some new players from investing in the platform.

Today, Battlestate Games revealed that in a two-month window, some 30,000 cheaters were banned.

But in March 2024, 33,000 cheaters were revealed to have been banned in two months.

And in January 2024, 11,000 cheaters were banned in two weeks.

And in September 2023, 16,600 cheaters were booted off the platform in one month.

It‚Äôs great that we‚Äôre getting a rolling tally of the number of cheaters banned, but the figure is either growing or fluctuating wildly. It‚Äôs no easy thing to stay ahead of today‚Äôs hackers and malicious operators, but it‚Äôs arguably the number one issue in Escape from Tarkov, and it doesn‚Äôt seem to be improving enough to fill players with confidence.

That and the recent controversy surrounding ‚ÄòThe Unheard Edition‚Äô is enough to make any Tarkov player baulk at the idea of investing a sizeable amount of time in the game.

Once again, Battlestate Games named and shamed the thousands of cheaters, providing a spreadsheet with the name of every cheater banned from the game in this wave. There are some interesting names on the list, and fans typically scour these pages for the names of big streamers ‚Äì not that they‚Äôd be named by Battlestate, of course‚Ä¶

item.title: Triple-A Publishers Are Dooming Themselves, But Maybe That‚Äôs Not Such A Bad Thing
item.content:encoded:
https://aftermath.site/aftermath-hours-podcast-animal-well-1000xresist

The video game industry is clearly in a transition period, and even though the full effects won‚Äôt be felt for years, we‚Äôre already getting hit by reverberations. Triple-A games have been few and far between recently while indies have been absolutely flourishing ‚Äì and getting some much-deserved shine from the press and public. On this week‚Äôs episode of Aftermath Hours, we discuss why a less triple-A-heavy future might not be such a bad thing.

Chris, Riley, and I begin by discussing Assassin‚Äôs Creed Shadows, which is set in feudal Japan and stars two main characters: a ninja and a samurai. It looks more interesting than the past few games in the series, if nothing else! Of course, since the ninja is a woman and the samurai is black, a certain subset of gamers are Big Mad. We (begrudgingly) talk about them, too. Then we move on to Animal Well, an unexpected Metroidvania-but-not hit that came out last week. Chris loves it, Riley doesn‚Äôt get it. (Gentle) fireworks ensue. 

After that, we talk about the recent flood of extremely good indie games and how triple-A publishers ‚Äì who‚Äôve chosen to go all in on a small handful of big hits, at the expense of everything else ‚Äì have forgotten how to make these types of games that there‚Äôs clearly still a hunger for. 1000xResist is basically a new Nier while Nier‚Äôs actual creator is off making gacha games. Dread Delusion is a spiritual successor to Morrowind in the year of our lord 2024. Cryptmaster is‚Ä¶ well, Crypmaster is just cool as hell. 

You can find this week's episode below and on Spotify, Apple, or wherever else you prefer to listen to podcasts. If you like what you hear, make sure to leave a review so that we can eventually fund Chris‚Äô idea for a Splinter-Cell-esque spies-versus-mercs-style multiplayer game, except it‚Äôs ninja-vs-samurai and it‚Äôs set in feudal Japan. It practically sells itself!

Here‚Äôs an excerpt from our conversation:

Chris: I think [Animal Well] hits at the right time, which is ‚Äì narratively, I guess ‚Äì indies are having a bigger moment now specifically because of the environment that we‚Äôre in. Because big companies don‚Äôt know how to handle small-to-medium-sized games anymore. And so, to just have this one drop and to be like ‚ÄúOh, this is a perfect game. What was stopping [bigger companies] from doing that?‚Äù Particularly relative to all the Microsoft shit and the Square Enix shit, where they don‚Äôt know how to market these small and medium-sized games. 

You had a great week this week of indie titles ‚Äì more than I could play. I actually tried to play all of them. I was playing Cryptmaster earlier, and that game is so fucking good. That game is really funny. There‚Äôs just a lot of games out. There‚Äôs a lot of bangers in a row. And it just comes at a time when it doesn‚Äôt seem like any big publisher knows what the fuck they‚Äôre doing. 

Riley: I think it‚Äôs [a byproduct of] something we saw a lot this week with Square and Ubisoft and with some earnings reports last week. All these companies are like ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre pivoting to less games.‚Äù And you have in contrast to that all these killer indies, and a big company can‚Äôt just say ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs do that!‚Äù I‚Äôm sure there‚Äôs somebody in a room somewhere demanding Ubisoft‚Äôs Balatro or whatever the heck. But are the big companies lumbering in the wrong direction, or is it like Luke‚Äôs article posited: Have indies kind of‚Äì I don‚Äôt want to say risen to fill a gap, because they‚Äôve always existed. But what is it that‚Äôs letting this moment happen? 

Chris: If there was a big, forgettable release right now, would we be caring about [these games]?

Riley: But there have been, though. What happened to Rise of the Ronin? That came and went, huh?  

Chris: Well, that came out the exact same day as Dragon‚Äôs Dogma 2. That was just really bad timing on their part. Also, it‚Äôs a medium-sized game.

But yeah, Crow Country, Animal Well‚Ä¶

Nathan: Cryptmaster, 1000xResist‚Ä¶

Chris: 1000xResist, which I did play a little bit of, though not enough to really give it an assessment. 

Riley: People say good stuff about it.

Nathan: Yeah, people are saying wildly good stuff. Some are saying it‚Äôs one of the best games ever.

Chris: It‚Äôs weird! I said it looks almost like Second Life. I don‚Äôt say that in a negative way, but it looks like some shit made in Unity. Not in a bad way; it has this affect of [being] sort of a narrative, Nier-type of game about the experience of diaspora. It has this high concept of going back into digital memories, and there‚Äôs clearly a lot there. It looks really interesting. It‚Äôs like if the kind of lesbian that wears Fox Racing gear to raves talked only in riddles. It‚Äôs like ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt actually know what you‚Äôre saying, but it‚Äôs fascinating.‚Äù 

It‚Äôs definitely got that sort of queer Nier Automata affect to it, but done in an indie game. Which I also like because it‚Äôs like, Yoko Taro‚Äôs not gonna make a Nier game; we‚Äôve got one at home.   

Nathan: I find it all interesting because there‚Äôs clearly room for these games, and there‚Äôs clearly hunger for these games. But then you have Square Enix, who had this strategy for a while of putting out some smaller games, and a lot of those games I think found audiences. People clearly love a lot of them, like Triangle Strategy. But those games did not meet ‚Äúsales expectations.‚Äù And of course Square Enix has always been really bad at predicting these things.  

But you have these companies that could create a lot of these smaller games. They have the means to do it, but it‚Äôs not going to please their shareholders enough. And so they‚Äôre pivoting to these much bigger games that represent this kind of horrible roll of the dice. It‚Äôs like ‚ÄúWell, if this game succeeds at the scale we hope it will and expect it to, then we have our big hit ‚Äì our Fortnite-sized, decade-lasting hit.‚Äù But if not, that is hundreds of millions of dollars down the drain. You‚Äôve got to lay tons of people off. You‚Äôre basically done. They‚Äôre betting it all on these titanic projects, and that just doesn‚Äôt seem wise.

Chris: The shit that makes me so mad about Square Enix is, their strategy of exclusivity was always going to be a bad idea. That was always going to bite them in the ass, particularly given the install base of the PS5. On top of that, they just don‚Äôt know how to market stuff. I know that‚Äôs an easy excuse, but they don‚Äôt try. I think that if you gave Harvestella to Atlus, they would have known how to deal with that. That would have been an interesting game for them to pitch. Square Enix was just not a good shepherd of it.    

Because I hate myself a little bit ‚Äì or like inflicting pain on myself ‚Äì I went back and read a year-end review from the president of Square Enix. And it starts like ‚ÄúThis was the year of the metaverse‚Äù and then proceeds to lay out all the shit they wasted time, energy, and money on for the last three years: crypto scams, NFTs, AI horseshit. Every hit you can think of ‚Äì of a scam or a bad idea ‚Äì they‚Äôve been really into. What if you spent any of that time marketing these little games? Maybe you would be in less of a bad place than you are now. Maybe if you weren‚Äôt banking on a trilogy that takes ten years to make, of one game with an increasingly smaller install base and fewer people that are on board every single time, maybe you wouldn‚Äôt have this issue. But they‚Äôre baking on this [less is more] strategy, and I think it‚Äôs not going to work out for them. I think it‚Äôs going to be a bad idea ‚Äì just the shortsightedness of it all.

Nathan: It‚Äôs sad on one hand, because we are going to miss out on a lot of these smaller, more inventive games that Square Enix was making. But I guess the upside ‚Äì and we‚Äôre seeing it in real time ‚Äì is that other people will make games like that. Other people will take the reins and go from there. They‚Äôll be indies, and they‚Äôll be different. Instead of another Nier, it‚Äôs gonna be 1000xResist, which definitely doesn‚Äôt look as big-budget, but if the ideas are there and the game is fun to play, then are we really losing that much?

Riley: I like all these indie games. I‚Äôve definitely hit that age where shorter, smaller games are definitely more my speed than ‚ÄúHere‚Äôs some 60-hour big-budget thing that strains the limits of my PC.‚Äù It‚Äôs exciting too, now that we have Aftermath, that we can write about these games without stressing out as much ‚Äì which isn‚Äôt to say that we didn‚Äôt write about them at our other sites. But it was always a bit of a harder proposition. 

More different things, as opposed to fewer big things from big companies, just seems great to me. What does it mean for the broader industry? All these companies are having layoffs, and they employ far more people than a developer making an indie game. But I think it‚Äôs a good thing [for games], mostly.

item.title: Ito Card Game Getting Western Localization
item.content:encoded:
https://techraptor.net/tabletop/news/ito-card-game-getting-western-localization

A new beloved board game from Japan is coming overseas. Not a localization of a popular TTRPG like Bouken, or a translated licensed work like the Shin Megami Tensei: Nocturne TTRPG. It is an official English-language of the Ito card game, courtesy of publisher Arcane Wonders.

The Ito Card Game English Localization Announcement

According to an official press release, the Ito card game is a wildly popular, easy-to-learn cooperative card game. It is designed by Mitsuru Nakamura and has gained over 300,000 fans in its native region.

In Ito, each player is given a secret number. This number can be between 1 and 100. From here, players need to work together to put their secret numbers in order on the board. Each player can provide clues to one another about what number is theirs based on several categories. They cannot directly tell their teammates their number.

The English localization of the Ito card game carries a mark of status. Not only is Arcane Wonders publishing the game for English-speaking territories, it will be distributed under their Dice Tower Essentials line. This is a curated line of board game whose titles include Onitama, Aquatica, and Smartphone Inc.

The Dice Tower Essentials line titles are handpicked by prolific board game reviewer Tom Vaesel, the same Tom Vaesel behind The Dice Tower podcast and designer of Vicious Fishes and the Nothing Personal series.

"We are incredibly excited to partner with Arclight Games to bring Ito to a global audience," said Robert Geistlinger, President of Arcane Wonders. "We believe that Ito perfectly embodies the spirit of the Dice Tower Essentials line of games. Its engaging gameplay and universal appeal make it a perfect addition to any gamer's collection."

The English version of the Ito card game will retain all of the elements that made the original game great. In addition, it will add cards to randomize category selection. The game is set to make its English debut October 2024.

Since everyone has their own unique playstyle, XDefiant allows you to choose a particular faction to gain distinct abilities. Each group excels in various fields, from support strategies to tactical espionage. Here‚Äôs a look into all XDefiant factions and their abilities.

All XDefiant Factions and abilities

XDefiant offers five factions to choose from, with the following groups:

  • Libertad: Support team
  • Phantoms: Specializes in defense
  • Echelon: XDefiant spies with emphasis on sneaking tactics
  • Cleaners: A fiery squad that focuses on offense
  • DedSec: Cyber Attackers that can mess with an enemy‚Äôs equipment

Thanks to the wide variety of factions, it should be easy enough to pick the right one based on your playstyle. But, since each XDefiant faction comes with distinct abilities, we‚Äôll break them all down to give you a better idea:

Libertad

XDefiant‚Äôs Freedom Fighters excel in support roles with their handy healing abilities. They are known as ‚Äúexpert medics‚Äù whose mission is to free those in their Caribbean nation of Yara. Take advantage of this faction‚Äôs many healing items to last longer in the field. 

  • Abilities:

    • El Remedio Ability: Gas Canister with the power to heal friendlies until canceled or destroyed.
    • BioVida Boost Ability: Produces a wave that increases total health and regen for you and your allies.

Phantoms

Phantoms, also known as Shadow Team, use the power of advanced technology and shields to dominate matches. They are among the most challenging factions to eliminate due to their highly defensive strategies. 

  • Abilities:
    • Aegis Ultra: Perfect for close-quarters combat, using a plasma shield and electro-scattergun.
    • Hardened Health Passive Trait: Utilizes gene therapies to increase Health.
    • Mag Barrier Ability: Emits an electromagnetic barrier to block enemy attacks.
    • Blitz Shield Ability: Allows players to equip a tactical shield, including a shield bash with the Melee button.

Echelon

The Echelon faction focuses on espionage, playing the role of spies for the NSA‚Äôs Echelon initiative. If you enjoy sneaking operations, try this team, as they will appear invisible on the minimap. They also have the beneficial ability to showcase enemy locations to keep all allies informed. 

  • Abilities:
    • Sonar Goggles Ultra: Reveals enemy locations.
    • Low Profile Passive Trait: The player will not appear on the opposing side‚Äôs minimaps.

Cleaners

Although you would think Cleaners are tied to some form of cleaning, they are actually Pyro Technicians. They deal a hefty amount of damage to enemies using their fiery weapons. You‚Äôll get the chance to wield tools, like a flame thrower, to set the battlefield ablaze.

DedSec

Those who enjoy messing with the enemy can join XDefiant‚Äôs DedSec faction. These Cyber Attackers disrupt the opposing side‚Äôs plan by scrambling their HUD and taking control of their devices.
